stories.text:
Problems with the current SCOTUS decision on Roe as at

     https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/21pdf/19-1392_6j37.pdf
First problem.

Roe was egregiously wrong from the start."

Where does the relevance of 'egregious' come from? Even just for the meaning of the word, inside the Constitution the word never appears, and outside the Constitution there is weak consensus.

So, now all emotional adjectives are relevant in SCOTUS decisions?

If 'egregious' is relevant, can we argue about it? We will have to argue about all adjectives?

So, now to understand the Constitution, we have to argue about vague adjectives?

Second problem.

SCOTUS logic:

(1) Roe would make the Mississippi law invalid, that is, overrule it.

(2) Roe is flawed in its reasoning.

(3) Therefore Roe should be overruled, and it follows that the Mississippi law has nothing wrong with it and should stand.

So, we are to conclude that any law that Roe would overrule should be okay and stand? So, to make some radical, absurd law okay, just be sure that Roe would overrule it? That is, everything that Roe would overrule is okay?

That is, we now have a way to make any law A legal: Pass law B that is obviously unconstitutional but explicitly outlaws law A. Let the SCOTUS strike down law B. Then by this SCOTUS logic law A must now be okay!

Hmm.

Third problem.

"The Constitution makes no express reference to a right to obtain an abortion, and therefore those who claim that it protects such a right must show that the right is somehow implicit in the constitutional text."

So, except for what is in the Constitution, explicitly, implicitly, or via the 14th Amendment, there are NO 'rights'. In particular, states can pass any laws they want to take, that is restrict, any 'rights' they want. So, state by state, the rights people have are subject to the results of the 'democratic' process in that state. In particular, rights are subject to the "tyranny of the majority". Hmm.
